choices.text: Right upper quadrant pain and hepatomegaly
Nontender subcutaneous nodules over several large joints

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is evaluated by his primary care physician for dysuria. A urethral swab is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis. He receives appropriate antibiotic treatment. He returns to the clinic four weeks later complaining of pain in the knees, ankles, and lower back. Repeat testing is negative for both Chlamydia and Neisseria gonorrhea. Which additional finding might be expected on examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome) is a post-infectious autoimmune condition typically triggered by genitourinary infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis. It manifests with a triad of:

  • Arthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis affecting large joints
  • Urethritis or cervicitis
  • Conjunctivitis or uveitis

In this case, conjunctival injection is a common feature and part of the classical triad. The inflammation can cause redness due to vascular dilation and is commonly seen in young males following chlamydial urethritis.

  • Chlamydia trachomatis can cause significant conjunctival scarring, and in acute phases, conjunctival injection is a visible feature.
  • Conjunctival injection is usually due to inflammation of the conjunctival vessels, which are more superficial and move with the conjunctiva.

Explanation of Other Options:

Right upper quadrant pain and hepatomegaly (Option A): Seen in viral hepatitis, not reactive arthritis.

Scleral icterus (Option B): Associated with jaundice, not a common feature in Reiter syndrome.

Nontender subcutaneous nodules (Option D): Seen in rheumatoid arthritis, not in reactive arthritis.

choices.text: Plain radiographs of the right knee

questions.text: A 43-year-old male with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes is brought to the emergency room for fever and pain in the right knee. His temperature is 101.2°F, pulse is 113/min, and blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. An examination of the right knee reveals limited range of motion, a moderate joint effusion, and severe tenderness to palpation. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Synovial fluid analysis is the diagnostic investigation of choice in a suspected case of septic arthritis before starting antibiotics.

  • The patient presents with fever, joint effusion, restricted motion, and tenderness - classic signs of acute septic arthritis.
  • Arthrocentesis (synovial fluid aspiration) is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and identify the causative agent.
  • Plain radiographs or MRI may help detect osteomyelitis, but should not delay aspiration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Plain radiographs of the right knee (Option A): May detect bony changes or osteomyelitis, but lacks sensitivity for early infection; not the first step.

MRI of the right knee (Option B): Sensitive for early bone or soft tissue involvement, but delays urgent aspiration.

CT of the right knee (Option C): Inferior to MRI in soft tissue resolution; not first-line in septic arthritis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl with no past medical history is evaluated by her paediatrician for pain in the bilateral hands, wrists, and feet that began 3 weeks earlier. Her physical examination is normal except for tenderness in the aforementioned joints. Her paediatrician orders plain films of the hands and wrists, which are normal, as well as a complete blood count, which shows a slightly decreased haemoglobin, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 55 mm/hr. Which of the following additional tests would likely be positive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is consistent with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA). Positive antinuclear antibodies are common in JRA; however, the other autoantibodies listed are rarely present in these patients. A positive rheumatoid factor in a patient with polyarticular arthritis should prompt consideration of a diagnosis other than JRA.

  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is a heterogeneous group of disorders of unknown cause that present with arthritis before age 16 and persist for at least 6 weeks. In contrast to RA, in JIA:
    1. Oligoarthritis is more common,
    2. Systemic disease is more frequent,
    3. Large joints are affected more often than small joints,
    4. Rheumatoid nodules and rheumatoid factor are usually absent, and
    5. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) seropositivity is common.
  • The pathogenesis is unknown but similar to adult RA; risk factors include HLA and PTPN22 variants. Also, like adult RA, damage in JIA appears to be caused by TH1 and TH17 cells and cytokines produced by these and other inflammatory cells.
  • Treatment is similar to adult RA, with some success in using an IL-6 receptor antibody in the systemic form. Long-term prognosis of JIA is very variable. Although many affected individuals have chronic disease, only about 10% develop serious functional disability.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anti-dsDNA (Option A): Highly specific for SLE, rarely positive in JIA.

Anti-Smith (Option B): Specific but not sensitive marker for SLE, uncommon in JIA.

Rheumatoid factor (Option D): Rare in JIA; if present, consider other diagnoses like early-onset RA.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with well-controlled hypertension and dyslipidemia presents to his family physician for right knee pain. He denies any preceding factors. The pain started three days prior to his visit and is severe and constant. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation, mild decreased range of motion, and no overlying erythema. Provocative testing (anterior and posterior drawer tests, McMurray test, and varus and valgus stress tests) is normal. Plain radiographs of the right knee show extensive chondrocalcinosis. Synovial fluid analysis shows multiple rhomboidal and square-shaped crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The finding of square and rhomboid-shaped crystals in the synovial fluid is diagnostic of calcium pyrophosphate disease. Crystals in gout are typically needle-shaped and negatively birefringent, whereas the crystals seen in calcium phosphate disease are typically weakly positively birefringent.

  • One would not expect to find crystals in synovial fluid in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, or osteomyelitis.
  • Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudogout, usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years and becomes more common with increasing age. The genders and races are equally affected. CPPD is divided into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types.
  • The autosomal dominant variant is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel, resulting in crystal deposition and arthritis relatively early in life. Various disorders, including previous joint damage, hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, and diabetes, predispose to the secondary form.
  • Studies suggest that articular cartilage proteoglycans, which normally inhibit mineralisation, are degraded, allowing crystallisation around chondrocytes. As in gout, inflammation is caused by activation of the inflammasome in macrophages.
  • Morphology: The crystals first develop in the articular cartilage, menisci, and intervertebral discs, and as the deposits enlarge, they may rupture and seed the joint. The crystals form chalky, white friable deposits, which are seen histologically in hematoxylin- and eosin-stained preparations as oval blue-purple aggregates. Individual crystals are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 µm in greatest dimension, and are positively birefringent. Inflammation is usually milder than in gout.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteomyelitis (Option A): Involves bone, not primarily joint; presents with systemic toxicity and elevated inflammatory markers, and is confirmed via MRI or bone scan.

Gout (Option B): Characterised by needle-shaped, negatively birefringent urate crystals; primarily affects the 1st MTP joint; not associated with chondrocalcinosis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D): Typically symmetric polyarthritis; synovial fluid does not show crystals; associated with RF and anti-CCP antibodies.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for a rash that started 1 week prior to his visit. The rash is erythematous, is located on the right lower leg, and has an area of central clearing with a small necrotic centre. He is treated with a 10-day course of clindamycin. The rash resolves; however, two months later, he presents complaining of new intermittent pain in both knee joints. On examination, there is slight right hemifacial weakness, which involves the forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The skin lesion described is classic for erythema migrans. Erythematous lesions with necrotic centres can be seen in cellulitis; however, central clearing of the lesion would never be seen in cellulitis.

  • The late manifestation of arthritis and cranial nerve palsy is extremely suggestive of Lyme disease.
  • Neither a brain abscess nor a brain metastasis would cause cranial nerve VII palsy.
  • With no other systemic symptoms, and given the fact that Lyme disease is much more common than Whipple's disease, it is incorrect. Such skin changes are not usually associated with Gaucher's disease.
  • It is caused by infection with the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted by deer ticks of the Ixodes ricinus complex.
  • In its classic form, Lyme disease progressively involves multiple organ systems through three clinical phases. The initial infection of the skin, or early localised stage, is followed by an early disseminated stage involving skin, cranial nerves, heart, and meninges. If left untreated, arthritis, especially of the knee, occurs weeks to months after infection.

Lyme disease

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteomyelitis with brain abscess (Option A): Would typically present with systemic toxicity, local bone tenderness, and focal neurological signs from abscess, facial palsy with central clearing rash is not typical.

Osteosarcoma with metastasis (Option B): Presents with progressive localised bone pain and swelling; metastasis to the brain or CN VII is rare. Rash and bilateral knee pain are not typical.

Gaucher's disease (Option C): A lysosomal storage disorder presenting with hepatosplenomegaly, anaemia, and bone pain, but no erythema migrans or facial palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a manifestation of reactive arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reactive arthritis is a sterile inflammatory arthritis that typically follows infections, particularly gastrointestinal or genitourinary (e.g., Chlamydia, Shigella, Salmonella). It is characterised by the classic triad of:

  • Arthritis (commonly asymmetric and involving large joints)
  • Urethritis
  • Conjunctivitis

Bleeding into the joint (hemarthrosis) is not a feature of reactive arthritis.

  • Affects mostly young adults (30 per 100,000)
  • Strongly associated with HLA-B27
  • Often follows Chlamydia, Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, Campylobacter
  • May present with: Enthesitis, Achilles tendinitis, plantar fasciitis, sausage digits, and extra-articular manifestations like skin lesions or mucosal ulcers
  • The chronic phase may resemble ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation of Other Options:

Joint pain (Option A): Common manifestation; often presents as asymmetric arthritis of knees, ankles, or feet.

Urethritis (Option B): Part of the classic triad; inflammation of the urethra post-infection.

Conjunctivitis (Option C): Ocular involvement is typical and seen in a subset of patients.

questions.text: Which of the following joints is characteristically involved in Rheumatoid Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) classically involves small joints of the hands and feet, particularly:

  • Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints
  • Wrist joints

This distribution is symmetric and helps distinguish RA from other forms of arthritis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Spine (Option A): RA rarely affects the spine; cervical spine involvement may occur in advanced stages, but is not characteristic.

Sacroiliac joint (Option B): Not a typical feature of RA; more commonly involved in seronegative spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis.

Wrist joint (Option C): Wrist is frequently involved, but not as specific as the simultaneous involvement of the MCP and PIP joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is an extra-articular manifestation of Rheumatoid Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a systemic autoimmune disease with numerous extra-articular manifestations that may involve the eyes, heart, lungs, skin, and other organs. These systemic features result from the widespread inflammatory activity of RA.

questions.text: Anti-RA antibodies belong to which immunoglobulin class?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid factor (RF), a commonly used diagnostic marker in RA, is an IgM antibody that targets the Fc portion of IgG. Although other autoantibodies are also associated with RA, such as anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs), rheumatoid factor is classically of the IgM class.

  • RA is associated with autoantibodies, including:
    • Rheumatoid factor (IgM against IgG Fc portion)
    • Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs)
    • Anti-carbamylated protein antibodies
  • IgM RF is present in ~80% of RA patients, making it a highly characteristic immunoglobulin class in RA.
  • Other isotypes (IgA, IgG) may also be present, but are less typical.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following shows Tophus as a pathognomonic characteristic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tophus formation is a hallmark morphological feature of gout, characterised by large aggregates of urate crystals surrounded by foreign body giant cell reaction, most commonly in joints and soft tissues.

  • Gout shows four key pathologic features:
    1. Acute arthritis
    2. Chronic tophaceous arthritis
    3. Tophi in joints and soft tissues
    4. Gouty nephropathy
  • Acute gouty arthritis:
    • Dense inflammatory infiltrates with neutrophils in the synovium
    • Urate crystals are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent
    • Synovium is edematous, hyperemic, and infiltrated with lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages
  • Chronic tophaceous arthritis:
    • Caused by repetitive urate crystal deposition
    • Synovium becomes fibrotic and forms pannus
    • Cartilage is destroyed
  • Tophi:
    • Pathognomonic of gout
    • Located in cartilage, ligaments, tendons, and bursae
    • Composed of large urate crystal aggregates with a foreign body giant cell reaction
  • Gouty nephropathy:
    • Urate crystals/tophus deposition in renal interstitium/tubules
    • May lead to uric acid nephrolithiasis and chronic pyelonephritis

Gout

(A) Amputated great toe with white tophi involving the joint and soft tissues.

(B) Gouty tophus - an aggregate of dissolved urate crystals is surrounded by reactive fibroblasts, mononuclear inflammatory cells, and giant cells.

(C) Urate crystals are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent under polarised light.

Explanation of Other Options:

Multiple myeloma (Option A): Malignancy of plasma cells; does not present with tophi. Bone lytic lesions and M-protein are characteristic.

Cystinosis (Option C): A lysosomal storage disease; crystalline deposits occur in various organs but are not tophi.

Eale's disease (Option D): Idiopathic retinal vasculitis; not associated with urate crystal deposition or tophus formation.

questions.text: Which of the following inflammasome-mediated cytokines plays a central role in the inflammation observed in gout?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

IL-1 is a key cytokine released by activated macrophages in response to monosodium urate crystal deposition, triggering acute gouty inflammation.

  • Gout results from precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in joints.
  • The phagocytosis of these crystals by macrophages activates the inflammasome, leading to:
    • Production and release of IL-1.
    • Induction of other cytokines and chemokines, leading to neutrophil recruitment.
  • This cascade leads to acute inflammation, cartilage injury, and synovial damage.
  • IL-1, in particular, promotes:
    • Recruitment of inflammatory cells.
    • Secretion of proteases and enzymes that contribute to tissue damage.

Explanation of Other Options:

IL-4 (Option B): Involved in Th2 responses and allergy, not in gouty inflammation.

IL-5 (Option C): Stimulates eosinophils; unrelated to urate-mediated inflammation.

IL-6 (Option D): Elevated in many inflammatory conditions but not central in gout pathogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included among the predisposing factors for the development of gout?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gout typically develops between 20-30 years after the onset of hyperuricemia, not specifically after age 60.

  • Only about 10% of patients with hyperuricemia develop clinical gout. Other factors contribute to symptomatic gout:
  • Age of the individual and duration of the hyperuricemia. Gout usually appears after 20 to 30 years of hyperuricemia.
  • Genetic predisposition. In addition to the well-defined X-linked abnormalities of HGPRT, polymorphisms in genes involved with urate or ion transport and possibly inflammation are also associated with gout.

Predisposing factors contributing to the development of clinical gout in patients with hyperuricemia include:

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presented in the ER with colicky abdominal pain, diarrhoea, vomiting, and frothy urine. She gives a history of knee and ankle joint pains for which she was taking NSAIDs; she also complained of a purpuric rash on her buttocks and legs. On examination, her blood pressure was 140/89mmHg, pulse 78/minute, respiratory rate 17/minute. Blood tests reveal elevated creatinine 1.8mg/dL and raised IgA levels. The platelet count was also raised. Biopsy shows increased IgA levels in the mesangium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) is the correct answer based on the clinical triad of purpuric rash, arthralgia, and abdominal pain along with renal involvement and mesangial IgA deposits on biopsy.

  • Wegener's disease (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): A c-ANCA-associated necrotising vasculitis involving the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. Shows granulomas and necrosis on histology. Chest X-rays reveal nodules and infiltrates. Treated with methotrexate or azathioprine. (Option A)
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura: An IgA-mediated small-vessel vasculitis involving the skin (purpura), joints (arthralgia), GI tract (abdominal pain), and kidneys (hematuria/proteinuria). Commonly occurs after an upper respiratory infection. Renal biopsy shows IgA in the mesangium. Treated with NSAIDs, corticosteroids. (Option B)

  • Polyarteritis nodosa: A medium-vessel necrotising vasculitis affecting kidneys and other organs (except lungs). Associated with hepatitis B or C. p-ANCA positive. Biopsy shows transmural inflammation in arteries. (Option C)
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis): Affects small and medium arteries, seen in patients with asthma or allergies. Features include eosinophilia, airway inflammation, and systemic vasculitis. Treated with corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide. (Option D)

choices.text: More frequent in the upper extremities

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding reactive arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reactive arthritis is diagnosed clinically based on the classic triad of arthritis, nongonococcal urethritis or cervicitis, and conjunctivitis, typically following an infection.

  • Distribution: It most commonly affects the lower extremities, especially knees and ankles, not the upper extremities.
  • HLA-B27 status: Although associated with HLA-B27, not all patients are positive. The association is strong but not universal.
  • Joint involvement: It is usually asymmetric, affecting only a few joints (oligoarthritis).
  • Aetiology: Follows infections by organisms like Chlamydia, Yersinia, Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter.
  • Chronicity: If symptoms persist for more than 6 months, it is termed chronic reactive arthritis.
  • Extra-articular features: Conjunctivitis, urethritis, dactylitis, skin lesions, and cardiac valve involvement may be seen.

Explanation of Other Options:

More frequent in the upper extremities (Option A): Incorrect; it more commonly affects the lower extremities, particularly knees and ankles.

All patients are HLA-B27 positive (Option C): Incorrect; HLA-B27 is associated but not universally present.

It involves the joints symmetrically (Option D): Incorrect; the joint involvement is typically asymmetric oligoarthritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with acute pain and swelling in his right knee. On examination, the knee is warm, tender, and movement is restricted. His temperature is 37°C, and his WBC count is 12.6 × 109/L. Knee X-ray shows reduced joint space with calcification of articular cartilage. Synovial fluid aspiration shows no bacterial growth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is pseudogout, also called Calcium Pyrophosphate Deposition Disease (CPPD). It classically presents in elderly individuals with monoarticular arthritis, especially involving the knee joint. The hallmark is calcification of articular cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) seen on radiographs.


Explanation of Other Options:

Gout (Option A): Presents with negatively birefringent needle-shaped urate crystals; commonly involves the 1st MTP joint (podagra). Knee involvement is possible but usually shows soft tissue tophi, not chondrocalcinosis.

Psoriatic monoarthropathy (Option B): Usually associated with psoriasis. It can involve large joints but typically has a known cutaneous history and lacks crystal deposition.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D): Involves small joints symmetrically and is associated with systemic symptoms. Radiologic findings include joint space narrowing and erosions, not cartilage calcification.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman falls from a ladder and sustains a fracture of the distal humerus with intra-articular extension. Several days after surgery, she develops acute pain, swelling and redness of the involved elbow, fever and chills. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sudden onset of monoarticular joint inflammation with systemic features following trauma or surgery is suggestive of acute bacterial (suppurative) arthritis, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Bacterial infections that cause acute suppurative arthritis usually enter the joints from distant sites by hematogenous spread. In neonates, however, contiguous spread from underlying epiphyseal osteomyelitis may occur.
  • influenzae arthritis predominates in children younger than 2 years of age, S. aureus is the main agent in older children and adults, and gonococcus is prevalent during late adolescence and young adulthood. Individuals with sickle cell disease are prone to infection with Salmonella.
  • These joint infections affect the sexes equally, except for gonococcal arthritis, which is seen mainly in sexually active women. Individuals with deficiencies of complement components (C5, C6, C7, or C9) are susceptible to disseminated gonococcal infections and hence arthritis.
  • The classic presentation is the sudden development of an acutely painful, warm, and swollen joint that has a restricted range of motion. Systemic findings of fever, leukocytosis, and elevated sedimentation rate are common.
  • In 90% of nongonococcal cases, the infection involves only a single joint, most commonly the knee, followed in decreasing frequency by the hip, shoulder, elbow, wrist, and sternoclavicular joints.
  • The axial joints are more often involved in drug users. Joint aspiration is diagnostic if it yields purulent fluid in which the causative agent can be identified. As mentioned earlier, cartilage has limited repair potential, so prompt recognition and effective antimicrobial therapy are vital to prevent permanent joint destruction.

Staphylococcal Arthritis

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteomyelitis (Option A): Usually involves bone, not joint; often subacute; not typically associated with intra-articular purulent fluid.

Meningococcal arthritis (Option C): Occurs in disseminated meningococcemia, less common than staph; more often polyarticular.

Gout (Option D): Sudden joint pain but involves deposition of monosodium urate crystals; more common in the big toe; no purulent fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following would be most in keeping with the diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is almost exclusively a disease of individuals above 50 years of age and is characterised by pain and morning stiffness in the proximal muscles.

  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory rheumatic condition characterised clinically by aching and morning stiffness about the shoulders, hip girdle, and neck. It can be associated with giant cell arteritis (GCA, also known as Horton disease, Horton giant cell arteritis, and temporal arteritis); the two disorders may represent different manifestations of a shared disease process.
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is almost exclusively a disease of adults over the age of 50, with a prevalence that increases progressively with advancing age.
  • Acute-phase reactants are elevated in virtually all patients with PMR. Head-to-head studies of the diagnostic value of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are few, but in clinical experience, the CRP is a more useful index of inflammation.
  • Other laboratory findings are nonspecific: A normocytic anaemia may be present, and the white blood cell and platelet counts are usually normal, though thrombocytosis can occur as part of a general acute inflammatory response.
  • Autoantibodies, including rheumatoid factor (RF) and anticyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, are usually negative in PMR, and if positive, an alternative diagnosis of late-onset rheumatoid arthritis (RA) should be considered. On the other hand, it should be borne in mind that approximately 10 per cent of the older adult population has a positive RF (usually at a low titre) without evidence of RA.

Explanation of Other Options:

Erythema nodosum (Option A): Not associated with PMR; seen in conditions like sarcoidosis or infections.

Loss of vision (Option B): Feature of GCA, not PMR itself.

Raised creatine kinase (Option D): CK levels are normal in PMR; elevated CK suggests polymyositis.

Reference: UpToDate: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis-of-polymyalgia-rheumatica

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with pseudogout?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chondrocalcinosis is a classic radiological finding associated with pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease or CPPD).

  • CPPD involves calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition in articular cartilage, menisci, and intervertebral discs.
  • These deposits often rupture into the joint, leading to an inflammatory response that mimics osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Crystals are birefringent and rhomboid-shaped under polarised light.
  • Radiographically, CPPD manifests as chondrocalcinosis - linear calcification within articular cartilage.

Calcium deposition in Joints

Explanation of Other Options:

Bamboo spine (Option A): Seen in ankylosing spondylitis due to syndesmophyte fusion of vertebrae.

Pencil-in-cup erosion (Option C): Characteristic of psoriatic arthritis due to marginal bone resorption and proliferation.

Overhanging margin erosion (Option D): Classical of gout due to tophaceous erosion with sclerotic overhanging edges.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presented to the dental OPD with complaints of posterior gingival swelling for 4 weeks, which has been gradually increasing in size. X-ray shows an expansile multilocular radiolucency with a well-defined, corticated border arising from the mandible. Excision of the lesion was performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology shows a classic ameloblastoma, characterised by peripheral palisading of columnar basal cells and central stellate reticulum-like cells.

  • Ameloblastoma arises from odontogenic epithelium.
  • Microscopically, it displays:
    • Peripheral columnar basal cells with palisading
    • Basal nuclei are hyperchromatic and polarised away from the basement membrane.
    • Suprabasal cells are loosely arranged, non-cohesive, and resemble the stellate reticulum.
    • May show epithelial invagination, oedema, and separation.
  • Radiologically, the lesion shows expansile, multilocular radiolucency with corticated margins.
  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour requiring complete surgical excision to prevent recurrence.

Explanation of Other Options:

Basal cell carcinoma (Option A): Skin malignancy arising from basal epidermal cells; does not involve the mandible or present as a multilocular jaw lesion.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Shows keratin pearls and cellular atypia with invasive behaviour; lacks the ameloblastoma pattern.

Dentigerous cyst (Option D): Developmental cyst enclosing the crown of an unerupted tooth; lined by non-keratinised epithelium and lacks palisading basal cells.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with painless swelling below the right ear that has been growing slowly for about a year. Physical examination confirms a cystic lesion. Fine-needle aspiration returns scanty brown fluid, which microscopically consists of a mixture of lymphoid cells and epithelial cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm. A biopsy of the mass is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Warthin tumour (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) is the second most common benign salivary gland neoplasm, occurring almost exclusively in the parotid gland. It is typically seen in older men and is strongly associated with smoking. The tumour is well-encapsulated and characteristically shows:

  • Cystic spaces lined by a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells (inner columnar, outer cuboidal)
  • Dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centres
  • Abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm in oncocytic cells
  • Commonly bilateral or multifocal in up to 10-15% of cases

Explanation of Other Options:

Acinic cell carcinoma (Option A): Malignant salivary gland tumour showing serous acinar differentiation. Cells have basophilic granular cytoplasm and lack the oncocytic-lymphoid combination seen in Warthin tumour.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option B): Malignant tumour with perineural invasion and cribriform ("Swiss cheese") pattern; lacks lymphoid stroma.

Pleomorphic adenoma (Option C): Most common benign salivary gland tumour with biphasic pattern (epithelial + myxochondroid stroma), unlike the purely oncocytic and lymphoid architecture of Warthin tumour.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient complains of postauricular swelling for the past 3 months. He reports a gradual increase in size and the recent onset of pain. Following radiological evaluation, a mass in the parotid gland was excised and sent for histopathological examination (image shown below). Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathological image shows epithelial and myoepithelial cells forming ducts and tubules within a background of myxoid and chondroid stroma, characteristic of pleomorphic adenoma.

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumour.
  • Histology shows a mix of:
    • Epithelial elements forming ducts, tubules, and strands
    • Myoepithelial cells in sheets
    • Chondromyxoid stroma (pink to basophilic matrix with cartilage-like areas)
  • Tumours are usually well-circumscribed and slowly growing, commonly arising in the parotid gland.

Explanation of Other Options:

Warthin tumour (Option B): Typically occurs in smokers; characterised by cystic spaces lined by a double layer of oncocytic epithelium with lymphoid stroma. It lacks the cartilaginous/myxoid stroma seen here.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option C): Malignant tumour showing "Swiss cheese" appearance due to cribriform architecture with hyaline basement membrane deposits, not seen in this image.

Basal cell carcinoma (Option D): Shows peripheral palisading of nuclei with cleft formation between tumour islands and stroma, not a feature of the given histology.

choices.text: Arises in relation to unerupted teeth
Mandibular third molar is a common site

questions.text: True about dentigerous cyst:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dentigerous cyst is the most common developmental odontogenic cyst, and all the given options are true:

  • Origin: Arises around the crown of an unerupted tooth due to the accumulation of fluid between the developing tooth and the dental follicle.
  • Common site: Most frequently associated with impacted mandibular third molars (wisdom teeth).
  • Location: More common in the mandible than in the maxilla.
  • Histology: Lined by thin stratified squamous epithelium with frequent chronic inflammatory infiltrates in the connective tissue wall.
  • Radiology: Presents as a unilocular radiolucency around the crown of an unerupted tooth.
  • Management: Surgical removal is curative.

(Other options are ruled out)

questions.text: The most common malignant salivary gland tumour is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most frequent malignant tumour of the salivary glands.

  • Represents the most common malignant salivary gland neoplasm.
  • It frequently involves the parotid gland, but also occurs in submandibular and minor salivary glands.
  • Histologically composed of mucous, intermediate, and squamous cells.
  • Low-grade tumours may resemble benign neoplasms; high-grade variants are aggressive and resemble squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Prognosis depends on the tumour grade and extent of invasion.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Newly erupted teeth are covered by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nasmyth's membrane (primary enamel cuticle) is a delicate tissue layer covering newly erupted teeth, derived from the reduced enamel epithelium (REE).

  • It is secreted by ameloblasts after enamel formation is complete.
  • Composed primarily of basal lamina and reduced enamel epithelium.
  • Function:
    • Protects enamel from resorption during eruption.
    • Helps tooth eruption by secreting desmolytic enzymes that remove the dental sac.
    • Facilitates fusion of REE with oral epithelium → bloodless tooth eruption.
  • Worn off naturally with mastication or brushing.

Explanation of Other Options:

Perikymata (Option A): Surface markings (incremental lines) seen on enamel, not a membrane.

Fibrous tissue (Option C): Present in the dental sac, not directly covering the erupting enamel.

All of these (Option D): Incorrect, only Nasmyth’s membrane directly covers erupting enamel.

questions.text: The most common cancer of the oral cavity, histologically, is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) accounts for approximately 95% of cancers of the head and neck, including those of the oral cavity.

  • SCC is the most frequent histologic type of cancer affecting the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, and upper aerodigestive tract.
  • It most commonly affects middle-aged individuals with a history of tobacco and alcohol use.
  • HPV-related SCCs are more common in the oropharynx, while classical SCCs in the oral cavity are associated with tobacco, alcohol, and betel nut use.
  • Histologically, these tumours show dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, or minimally invasive carcinoma, especially in lesions like erythroplakia and leukoplakia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): Rare in the oral cavity; more typical of salivary glands or the gastrointestinal tract.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option C): Arises from minor salivary glands, not the most common in the oral cavity.

Odontogenic carcinoma (Option D): A Rare tumour originating from odontogenic epithelium; much less common than SCC.
